Nuguid Writing – review & editing b c Davide Ferri Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition Supervision b Qingcai Liu Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a Krocher Oliver Kröcher Writing – review & editing b c a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, China b Paul Scherrer Institut, PSI, CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland Paul Scherrer Institut, PSI Villigen CH-5232 Switzerland Paul Scherrer Institut, CH-5232 Villigen PSI, Switzerland c Institute for Chemical Sciences and Engineering, École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland Institute for Chemical Sciences and Engineering, École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) Lausanne CH-1015 Switzerland Institute for Chemical Sciences and Engineering, École polytechnique fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL), CH-1015 Lausanne, Switzerland ⁎ Corresponding author. Mn-Ce/AC catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO x were deliberately loaded with various potassium salts (KCl, KNO3, and K2SO4) to investigate the influence of the counter-ions on the poisoning impact. Whereas K salts poisoning had only marginal impact on the textural properties of the catalysts, but it altered the chemical properties of the catalysts significantly. Potassium addition lowered the relative surface concentration of Mn4+ and M−O in Mn-Ce/AC catalyst, suggesting that K might occupy the oxygen vacancies around Mn atoms, thereby weakening the NH3 adsorption. The extent of inhibition strongly depended on the anion, with Cl− causing a higher degree of poisoning than that of either NO3 − or SO4 2−. While K+ could hinder NH3 adsorption, both NO3 − and SO4 2− provided new acid sites that could offset the deactivation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Low-temperature NH3-SCR Potassium salts poisoning Mn-Ce/AC catalyst Counter-ions 1 Introduction The importance of low-temperature selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitric oxides (NO x ) with NH3 is growing, due to the increasingly strict pollution regulations being imposed worldwide. Some mixed transition metal oxides were used for low-temperature SCR applications, but these catalysts were sensitive to be poisoned by harmful components in ultra-fine dust which was present in the flue gas even after dust removal [1,2]. Manganese is a suitable element for low-temperature SCR because of the easy gain and loss of electrons in the d shell which was responsible for its facile redox properties [3,4]. In an earlier study [5], we found that MnO x loaded on carbon-based support showed remarkable NO x conversion comparing to CeO x , VO x and FeO x containing catalysts. Furthermore, in an attempt to improve the oxidation potential of MnO x , we prepared a series of Mn-containing mixed oxides supported on carbon-based materials [6–8], within which Mn-Ce supported on activated carbon showed desirable SCR activity. In Mn-containing carbon-based catalysts, NH3 was considered to adsorb weakly on the oxygen atoms of both the carbonaceous support and the active components, and the SCR reaction occurred between ammonium ions and gas-phase NO [9,10]. SCR catalysts required high resistance to poisoning elements presented in industrial flue gases, especially alkali metals. Potassium-containing species were found to have more severe poisoning impact on the catalytic activity of Mn/TiO2 catalyst compared to that of containing Na and Mg species [11,12]. Alkali metals deactivated V2O5-WO3/TiO2 (VWT) catalysts by interacting with the Brønsted acid sites, leading to a decline of acidity, surface-adsorbed oxygen, and the reducibility of vanadium species [2,13]. In addition, anions (e.g., Cl−, NO3 −, SO4 2−) commonly presented in the flue gas and also affected the catalytic activity [1,13]. Different potassium salts could lead to the deactivation of MnO x /TiO2 catalysts by poisoning the Brønsted acid sites, in addition to decreasing the reducibility and the surface area [13]. Although the nature of K salts showed limited influence on the inhibition of NH3 adsorption, it affected the catalyst performance significantly. For instance, KCl exhibited a greater impact on the N2 selectivity than that of KNO3 in the low-mid temperature range [1]. Hence, it was important to investigate the influence of the counter-ions of potassium on the poisoning effect of the catalysts. In this work, the effects of various potassium salts (Cl−, NO3 − and SO4 2−) on the structure and low-temperature SCR activity of carbon-supported Mn-Ce catalysts were investigated. Fresh and poisoned catalysts were systematically characterized in order to clarify the effects of potassium and its counter ions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Coal-based activated carbon (Xinhua Chemical Plant, China) was used as catalyst support. The samples were crushed into particles (16 −20 mesh), which were then washed and dried. To improve the pore structure, the samples were treated with nitric acid (67 wt%) at 80 °C for 10 h, followed by washing until a pH value of ~7 was reached, and then drying. This support was denoted as AC. In impregnation process, AC was impregnated with aqueous solutions of Mn(NO3)2 and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O precursors under sonication for 0.5 h and heated in a water bath at 50 °C for 8 h. The samples were then dried at 90 °C for 12 h, followed by calcinating under N2 atmosphere at 400 °C for 4 h. The obtained Mn-Ce/AC catalysts were labelled as MC/AC, with M being Mn and C being Ce, where the mole ratio of Mn/Ce was 7:3 for MC/AC catalyst, and the total weight of metal oxides loading was 10 wt%. Potassium-poisoned MC/AC and M/AC catalysts were prepared by the same impregnation process with aqueous solutions of KCl, KNO3 or K2SO4 to obtain a nominal loading of 0.5 wt%, 1 wt% and 2 wt% of potassium. Poisoned catalysts were then calcined in air at 300 °C for 4 h. The obtained poisoned catalysts were labelled as 2KCMC/AC, 2KNMC/AC and 2KSMC/AC, with 2KC being 2 wt% KCl, 2KN being 2 wt% KNO3 and 2KS being 2 wt% K2SO4. 2.2 Catalytic performance A fixed-bed quartz reactor (din = 8 mm, dout = 10 mm) loaded with 0.5 g of the catalyst (16 −20 mesh) was used for the SCR activity tests. The feed gas stream contained 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 11 vol% O2 and N2 as balance, with a total flow rate of 300 mL/min corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 12,000 h−1. Outlet gas concentrations were monitored by a flue gas analyzer (Antaris IGS, Thermo Fisher Scientific). NO x conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated according to the Eqs. (1 and 2): (1) NO x conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − [ NO x ] out [ N O x ] in ) × 100 % (2) N 2 selectivity = 1 − 2 N 2 O out [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in − NO x out − [ NH 3 ] out × 100 % where the subscripts in and out indicated the inlet and outlet concentrations at steady state, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The detailed characterizations of catalysts and the procedure of transient reaction experiments were displayed in the Supporting Information (SI). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization 3.1.1 Elemental analysis The actual contents of Mn, Ce and K in the catalysts were obtained by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), as indicated in Table 1. No apparent difference was found with the targeted amount of K and active components of Mn and Ce. The intended content of Mn and Ce was 3.4 wt% and 3.7 wt%, respectively. 3.1.2 BET results The BET specific surface area and pore volume of the fresh MC/AC catalyst were 230 m2/g and 0.121 cm3/g, respectively ( Table 2). The specific surface area of AC support was 243 m2/g (Table S1), which was a little bigger than that of MC/AC catalyst. This result indicated that 10 wt% metal oxides loading led to only a slight destruction of AC surface area. The addition of KCl, KNO3 and K2SO4 did not obviously alter the BET specific surface area of the catalysts, with the values ranging between 227 and 231 m2/g that corresponded to pore volumes in the range of 0.118 and 0.121 cm3/g. All catalysts showed the same typical type Ⅳ N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and similar pore diameter distribution ( Fig. 1a and b), and so was AC support (Fig. S1). Hence, the small difference in surface areas of the fresh and poisoned catalysts was considered to exert poor impact on the catalytic performance. 3.1.3 SEM results Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was applied to observe the morphology of catalysts, as shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S2. There was lots of irregular debris on the surface of all catalysts. Combined with BET data, it could be seen that the carbon-based catalysts had rich pore structure. Poisoning did not change the surface morphology of the catalysts significantly, as all the catalysts showed numerous debris on the surface. The KC-poisoned catalyst also showed no obvious changes compared to the fresh M/AC catalyst (Fig. 2e and f). 3.1.4 XRD results XRD results showed that poisoning by K+ with different counter-ions did not affect the catalyst structure significantly ( Fig. 3). All patterns contained a broad peak at 20 − 30° and a smaller peak at 40 − 45°, which were associated with the graphite crystallites of layered structure and the turbo-stratic graphite-like structure [14], respectively. This intrinsic structure of the carbon-based support was thoroughly discussed in our previous paper [8]. According to our previous study [8], the XRD profiles of carbon-based catalysts were noisy, which might cause masking of the characteristic peaks of the active component in low concentration. Nevertheless, the diffraction peaks of CeO2 could be observed in both fresh and poisoned catalysts. 3.1.5 XPS results Fig. 4 and Fig. S3 showed the X-ray photoelectron spectra of Mn, Ce, O and C elements, while the integral areas of each peak were listed in Table 3. Fig. 4a showed the Mn 2p region of the fresh catalyst and the K-poisoned catalysts with different counter-ions. The two broad peaks at ca. 641.3 eV and 653.1 eV corresponded to Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2, respectively [15,16]. Mn 2p3/2 peaks were fitted with three peaks centered at 645.5 − 644.7 eV, 641.8 − 641.3 eV and 640.3 − 639.9 eV, which could be assigned to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+, respectively [15,16]. After poisoning by K salts, the concentration of high valence state Mn4+ on the catalyst surface decreased compared to that of the fresh catalyst. Poisoning effects of K salts with different counter-ion on the Mn valence state were different. While the relative atomic ratio of Mn4+/Mn n+ on the fresh MC/AC catalyst was 18%, it decreased to 11% with KCl, 15% with KNO3 and 13% with K2SO4 (Table 3). Furthermore, the relative atomic ratio of Mn2+ in 2KCMC/AC catalyst was much higher than that of other catalysts. The signals of the Ce spectra (Fig. 4b) were fitted with two sets of characteristic peaks corresponding to Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2, which were denoted as v and u, respectively. The spectral lines denoted as v’ and u’ were attributed to surface Ce3+ species with 3d10 4 f1 electronic state, while v, v’’, v′’’, u, u’’ and u′’’ were assigned to surface Ce4+ species with 3d10 4 f0 electronic state [15,17]. The relative surface Ce3+/Ce n+ atomic ratio calculated from the XPS spectra decreased after K poisoning, which was similar to the trend of Mn4+ (Table 3). The Ce3+ surface concentration decreased from 25% in the fresh MC/AC catalyst to 19% in 2KCMC/AC catalyst, to 21% in 2KNMC/AC catalyst and to 23% in 2KSMC/AC catalyst. Fig. 4c showed the O 1 s region of the spectra of fresh and poisoned catalysts. The O 1 s spectra were fitted with two characteristic peaks, which were assigned to M−O groups (529.3 −530.1 eV), surface adsorbed O2 and/or carbanyl (CO) groups (532.0 −532.4 eV) [18]. Oxygenate surface groups were able to physisorbe NH3 by hydrogen bonding on oxygen atoms, suggesting that weakly adsorbed NH3 could be released at higher temperature from AC support [9]. The C 1 s spectra (Fig. 4d) were fitted with three characteristic peaks at around 288.5 − 289.0 eV, 284.3 − 284.6 eV and 283.4 − 283.5 eV, which could be assigned to carbonyl C (CO) and/or carboxyl C (O−CO), sp2 C (CC) and graphitic C (C–C), respectively [18]. Besides the discussed samples, the chemical state and the content of active elements were also obtained for M/AC and 2KCM/AC catalysts to distinguish the different poisoning effects on Mn compared to Mn-Ce, as shown in Fig. 6. The poisoned and fresh M/AC catalysts exhibited almost the same O distribution and similar behaviour of Mn n+ compared to that of MC/AC catalyst. 3.2 SCR performance The NO x conversion and N2 selectivity of fresh and poisoned MC/AC catalysts were shown in Fig. 7 for standard NH3-SCR reaction at a GHSV of 12,000 h−1. The NO x conversions of 2KCMC/AC, 2KNMC/AC and 2KSMC/AC catalysts were normalized according to the Eq. (S1), and the results were shown in Fig. S4a. For the fresh MC/AC catalyst, the NO x conversion increased with increasing temperature up to 200 °C and then decreased from 95% to 88% from 200 to 250 °C. The N2 selectivity exhibited a different trend as it remained almost stable in the range of 75 − 125 °C and then decreased with increasing temperature. This behaviour was explained by an increase of NH3 oxidation to the by-products NO and/or N2O [8,19]. For KC-poisoned catalysts, the NO x conversion decreased from 75 to 150 °C, and then increased from 150 to 250 °C. The high content of KCl caused severe deactivation. For the KN-poisoned catalysts, the poisoning effect on catalysts activity decline was relatively small compared to that of KC-poisoned and KS-poisoned catalysts (Fig. S4a). The NO x conversion of KS-poisoned catalysts decreased first and then increased with the increase of temperature (Fig. S4a). This behaviour was similar to that of KC-poisoned catalysts, but K2SO4 poisoning induced a lower degree of deactivation at comparable potassium content (Fig. S4a). In general, the effect of KCl on NO x conversion was the most severe among the K salts, while KNO3 exhibited the smallest effect. With respect to N2 selectivity, KCl poisoning and K2SO4 poisoning both had positive influence in the range of 175 − 250 °C, while KNO3 poisoning showed an adverse effect. To isolate the poisoning effect on the carbon support, Mn and Ce species, we synthesized different K-poisoned catalysts based on AC, M/AC and C/AC catalysts. The NO x conversions of K-poisoned catalysts based on AC, M/AC and C/AC catalysts were normalized according to the Eq. (S1), and the results were shown in Fig. S4. It was apparent that K poisoning had a positive impact on the NO x conversion of AC in the temperature range of 75 − 125 °C, otherwise it showed negative influence on NO x conversion as expected in the temperature range of 150 − 250 °C ( Figs. S4b and 8a). Fig. 8b showed that in the case of all K-poisoned M/AC catalysts, the NO x conversion exhibited a minimum of about 15% at 150 °C and the NO x conversion values decreased in the order KNO3 > KCl > K2SO4. K poisoning also influenced N2 selectivity to some extent, especially in the case of the KS-poisoned catalysts (Fig. 8e). K-poisoning caused an obvious inhibition of the SCR activity of C/AC catalyst (Fig. 8c) and slight change in N2 selectivity (Fig. 8f). 3.3 NH3-TPD analysis The results of the temperature programmed desorption (TPD) tests were shown in Fig. 9. The K-poisoned catalysts showed saturation of the NH3 adsorption in a short time and exhibited much less NH3 desorption compared with fresh MC/AC catalyst. The temperature required for NH3 desorption of the K-poisoned catalysts was also lower compared to the fresh catalyst. A distinct peak at ca. 270 °C was observed only for the fresh catalyst. In the temperature range of 100 − 300 °C, the K-poisoned catalysts showed a little difference in the amount of desorbed NH3. A small desorption peak occurred at around 600 °C on the KN- and KS-poisoned catalysts but was not observed in the case of the KC-poisoned samples. In the temperature range of 400 − 600 °C, the fresh catalyst also displayed a much larger NH3 desorption peak. The amounts of desorbed NH3 of the K-poisoned catalysts were in the order KNO3 > K2SO4 > KCl and the KC-poisoned catalysts showed almost no NH3 desorption in this temperature range. This difference indicated that K-poisoning affected not only the weak acid sites but also the strong acid sites. The strong acid sites in the temperature range of 400 − 600 °C were assigned to Lewis acid sites [9]. NH3 desorption in 100 − 300 °C region was assigned to weak NH3 adsorption on the AC support [20,21], while another peak was assigned to NH3 coordinated to the active component [9]. This meant that KCl poisoning block the active sites for NH3 adsorption and this blockage was further influenced by the nature of the counter-ion. The low temperature desorption of NH3 might be related to the decomposition of poorly stable [NH4·NH3]+ and/or adsorbed NH3 by hydrogen bonding with the oxygen atoms [9,22]. No other gases releasing from these samples were detected during the temperature program between 40 − 600 °C. Marbán reported a carbon-supported Mn3O4 catalyst which presented low (ca. 204 °C), medium (ca. 262 °C) and high (ca. 370 °C) temperature desorption peaks of NH3 [9]. Generally speaking, surface functional groups (CO, O−H, C−O and C−O−C) on carbon could act as acid sites thus adsorbing NH3 [5,8]. This particularly held true for oxygen-containing groups [20,21], which showed to exist on the MC/AC catalyst from XPS data (Fig. 5a) and our previous studies [5–8]. Oxygenated surface groups could adsorb NH3 by hydrogen bonding with the oxygen atoms [21], which suggested that NH3 was weakly adsorbed and could be released at low temperature. NH3 bonded to Brønsted acid sites as NH4 + could be attributed to the NH3 desorption between 350 and 540 °C [23]. 3.4 Transient reaction and in situ DRIFTS analysis In order to identify the intermediate species formed on the catalyst surface during transient reaction conditions, in situ DRIFTS were collected and the outlet gases concentration were recorded with the mass spectrometer. The outlet gases concentration during transient reaction experiments were shown in Fig. 10. Since large amounts of NH3 desorbed at ca. 200 °C according to the NH3-TPD data (Fig. 9), we selected 175 °C as the temperature for the transient reaction experiments. In the NH3 adsorption step, the sample was saturated with NH3 in a continuous flow of O2 and Ar. Before NH3 broke through MC/AC catalyst, N2O started to be released and decreased to a stable concentration level along with NH3 adsorption (Fig. 10a). According to a previous study [8], AC itself had very low SCR activity and it did not even release N2O. A similar behaviour as MC/AC catalyst was observed for pure MnO2 (Fig. S5). The concentration profiles for NH3, NO, N2O, and N2 during NH3 adsorption step were very similar for both catalysts (Fig. 10a and Fig. S5), implying that similar reactions might occur on MC/AC and MnO2 catalysts, with the presence of MnO x being the only common feature. This indicated that N2 and N2O formation might be due to the common existing of MnO x species. Therefore, we conducted the experiments of MnO2 catalyst for exploiting a sequence of NH3 adsorption, Ar purging, NH3 adsorption, and NH3 + O2 co-adsorption. N2 formation occurred almost simultaneously as N2O was released, while NO appeared when NH3 broke through the catalyst in agreement with the behavior of MC/AC catalyst. In the NH3 adsorption experiment, NH3 was directly oxidized by surface adsorbed oxygen to N2O and N2, which produced surface oxygen vacancies (Eqs. 3 and 4) [9]. After purging with Ar, NH3 was introduced to the catalyst but no sudden N2O generation occurred, which was due to the absence of available surface oxygen species. A significant increase in the content of N2O and NO was observed when O2 was added to the feed gas. This confirmed that N2O generation was related to the presence of surface oxygen. (3) Mn − V O − Mn + O 2 → Mn − O − Mn (4) Mn − V O − Mn + NH 3 → Mn − e − / V O − Mn + N 2 + N 2 O (5) Mn − V O − Mn + K + → Mn − K − Mn The difference of N2O production between the fresh and poisoned catalysts was in line with the difference of NO x conversions between the fresh and poisoned catalysts. Since most N2O originated from NH3 oxidation and it was reasonable to assume that K poisoning hampered NH3 adsorption and thus N2O formation. Fig. 10 showed that introducing NO to the catalysts could equilibrate with NH3 and then produced a sudden increase of N2. The amount of N2 generation was different between the fresh and K-poisoned catalysts, which was also in accordance with the NO x conversion values. This confirmed that pre-adsorbed NH3 could react with gas phase NO and/or adsorbed NO species. In the NH3 + O2 co-adsorption step, NH3 was again introduced to the catalysts for equilibrating with NO. Fig. 10a showed that a small sharp N2 peak formed at the beginning of NH3 step along with the N2O peak, which revealed that pre-adsorbed NO species could also react with NH3. During the SCR reaction process, it was remarkable to note that N2 concentrations on the fresh and poisoned catalysts were very similar to the maximal intensity of N2 formation peaks obtained during the NO adsorption step. This result implied that the Eley−Rideal mechanism dominated the SCR reaction on this type of catalyst, and NH3 adsorption preceded SCR reaction. The amount of adsorbed NH3 was calculated from the difference between the total inlet amount of NH3 and the outlet amount of NH3, which was shown in Table 4 and Fig. 11. Poisoned catalysts showed an apparent decrease in the amount of adsorbed NH3, especially in the case of KCl, which agreed well with the NH3-TPD results (Fig. 9). After purging with Ar and admittance of NO to the fresh and poisoned catalysts, the outlet concentrations of NO exhibited obvious differences. The amount of NO consumption of different K-poisoned catalysts showed the same order of their NO x conversions. In conclusion, the decrease in NH3 adsorption caused by K-poisoning resulted in a decrease of the amount of NO reacting in the SCR reaction. Fig. 12 showed the DRIFT spectra of the fresh and K-poisoned catalysts with different counter-ions collected at 175 °C. For the fresh MC/AC catalyst, a broad peak was observed in the region of 3400 − 3100 cm−1 after 30 min of NH3 adsorption, which was accompanied by a sharp peak at ca. 1603 cm−1 corresponding to NH3 adsorption on Lewis acid site [24]. These signals of NH3 on the fresh catalyst suggested the existence of adsorbed NH3 on the catalyst surface, which was in agreement with the NH3-TPD and MS results. In the case of the KC-poisoned catalysts, these two peaks for adsorbed NH3 could not be detected, suggesting that KCl poisoning had strong impact on the NH3 species adsorbed on the catalyst surface. As discussed above, K+ might interact with the catalytically active component, causing depletion of the acid sites and a severe decline of NH3 adsorption. In the case of the KN-poisoned catalyst, only one broad peak in the region 3400 − 3100 cm−1 was observed after 30 min of NH3 adsorption, which might be due to the counter-ion of NO3 − acting as acid sites. The spectra of the KS-poisoned catalyst showed the characteristic peak of NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites at ca. 1603 cm−1 but it was previously assigned to NH3 adsorbed on SO4 2− ions, which was shown to act as acid site [1,2]. When NO was introduced to the NH3 pre-adsorbed samples, two peaks at ca. 0.1528 cm−1 assigned to NH4NO3 and at ca. 1670 cm−1 corresponding to adsorbed NO2 were observed on the surface of the KN-poisoned catalyst [25], which was related to the existence of NO3 − ions on the catalyst surface and the formation of NH4NO3. 3.5 K-poisoning discussion K poisoning showed poor impact on the textural properties of the catalysts such as active component (ICP results), structure properties (BET and SEM results) and crystal structure (XRD results). Therefore, the cause of low activity might be assigned to chemical poisoning. As discussed in the in situ DRIFTS part, the Eley−Rideal mechanism dominated the SCR reaction of this type of catalyst and NH3 adsorption played a key role. The AC support exhibited intrinsic NO conversion activity (Fig. 8a), which was also influenced by the potassium salts. During the low temperature range of 75 − 125 °C, K poisoning showed a positive effect on the catalytic activity, while it inhibited the catalytic activity in the range 150 − 250 °C (Fig. S4b). This suggested that potassium salts were contributed to weak NH3 adsorption on the AC support, which acted as acid sites to adsorb NH3 through hydrogen bonding. Compared to the K-poisoned C/AC catalyst, the declines of normalized NO x conversion over the K-poisoned MC/AC catalysts were similar to that of K-poisoned M/AC catalysts (Fig. S5), confirming that the K-poisoning originated from the poisoning of the Mn active phase. After poisoning by potassium, the decline of Mn4+ surface ions was observed (Table 3), which was mirrored by the content of M−O, being consistent with the decrease in NO conversion rate (Fig. S4). Potassium might have a strong interaction with the Mn species, decreasing the amount of NH3 adsorption significantly and occupying the vacancies around Mn atoms (Eq. 5). With respect to the K-poisoned MC/AC catalysts, K-poisoning decreased the amount of adsorbed NH3 (Figs. 9 and 11); on the other hand, the counter-ion acted as acid sites to adsorb NH3 (Fig. 12c and d). In light of these two aspects, the decline of NO x conversion between 75 − 125 °C was slight, especially for the KN- and KS-poisoned catalysts. In the region of 150 − 200 °C, the K-poisoned MC/AC catalysts suffered from a severe decline in activity (Fig. S4a), while most of the NH3 weakly adsorbed by hydrogen bonding was also released (Fig. 9b). The inhibition of SCR activity was obviously different depending on the nature of the potassium counter-ions, with NO3 − and SO4 2− having less poisoning degree than that of Cl− (Fig. S4a). Several peaks corresponding to adsorbed NH3 were observed on the KN- and KS-poisoned catalysts by DRIFTS while none could be seen on the KC-poisoned catalyst (Fig. 12b). Furthermore, NH3-TPD experiments also showed the different behaviours between the catalysts poisoned by different potassium salts. No NH3 desorption peaks could be observed for the KC-poisoned MC/AC catalyst in the temperature range of 100 − 300 °C (Fig. 9). To conclude, KNO3 and K2SO4 poisoning showed a relative slight effect on SCR activity of MC/AC catalysts. Potassium could strongly decrease the activation of Mn species thereby hindering NH3 adsorption, but the NO3 − and SO4 2− counter-ions were able to produce new acid sites which could weaken the impact of K+ poisoning, while Cl− was not. Therefore, this explained the weaker deactivation observed with KNO3 or K2SO4 than that of KCl poisoning. 4 Conclusions The effects of various potassium salts (Cl−, NO3 − and SO4 2−) on the structure and low-temperature SCR activity of MC/AC catalysts were investigated. KCl exhibited the most severe impact on NO x conversion among the K salts while KNO3 had the smallest effect. With respect to N2 selectivity, KCl and K2SO4 poisoning had a positive influence, while KNO3 poisoning showed an adverse effect. The higher content of KCl caused severe deactivation. The Eley−Rideal mechanism dominated the SCR reaction of MC/AC catalysts, where adsorbed NH3 played a key role. K-poisoning suppressed the activity of adsorbed NH3, while the amount of desorbed NH3 was in the order of KNO3 > K2SO4 > KCl. K salts poisoning showed only slight impact on the textural properties of catalysts. Both Mn4+ and M−O concentrations decreased after poisoning by K salts. Potassium might have a strong interaction with the Mn species, thus decreasing significantly NH3 adsorption and occupying the vacancies around Mn atoms. coredata.dc:description: Mn-Ce/AC catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO x were deliberately loaded with various potassium salts (KCl, KNO3, and K2SO4) to investigate the influence of the counter-ions on the poisoning impact. Whereas K salts poisoning had only marginal impact on the textural properties of the catalysts, but it altered the chemical properties of the catalysts significantly. Potassium addition lowered the relative surface concentration of Mn4+ and M−O in Mn-Ce/AC catalyst, suggesting that K might occupy the oxygen vacancies around Mn atoms, thereby weakening the NH3 adsorption. The extent of inhibition strongly depended on the anion, with Cl− causing a higher degree of poisoning than that of either NO3 − or SO4 2−. While K+ could hinder NH3 adsorption, both NO3 − and SO4 2− provided new acid sites that could offset the deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Poisoning of Mn-Ce/AC catalysts for low-temperature NH3-SCR of NO by K+ and its counter-ions (Cl−/NO3 −/SO4 2−)
